[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer] Reserved (1 byte): A flags structure.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer] Reserved (1 byte):This field MUST be set to zero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer] Reserved (1 byte): This field is optional and will only be present if the Extended (0x0400) flag is set in the NotificationTypes field.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer]WantWholeStore (1 byte): A Boolean.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer,WantWholeStore (1 byte):] This value specifies whether the notification is scoped to the mailbox instead of a specific folder or message.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer] FolderId (8 bytes): An identifier.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, FolderId (8 bytes):] That is present when the WantWholeStore field is zero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, FolderId (8 bytes):] That is not present when it[the WantWholeStore field] is nonzero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, FolderId (8 bytes):] This value specifies the folder to register notifications for.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, FolderId (8 bytes):] If the notification is scoped to a specific folder, MessageId SHOULD be zero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer] MessageId (8 bytes): An identifier.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, MessageId (8 bytes):] That is present when the value of the WantWholeStore field is zero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, MessageId (8 bytes):] This field is not present when it[the WantWholeStore field] is nonzero.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, MessageId (8 bytes):] This value specifies the message to register notifications for.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Request Buffer, MessageId (8 bytes):] If the notification is scoped to a specific message, FolderId SHOULD specify the parent folder of the message.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopRegisterNotification ROP response buffer.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer] RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopRegisterNotification] this field is set to 0x29.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer]OutputHandleIndex (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer, OutputHandleIndex (1 byte):] This index MUST be set to the value specified in the OutputHandleIndex field in the request.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer] ReturnValue (4 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRegisterNotification ROP Response Buffer, ReturnValue (4 bytes):] This value specifies the status of the ROP.
[In RopNotify ROP]The RopNotify ROP provides notification event data to the client.
[In RopNotify ROP]There is no request buffer for this ROP.
[In RopNotify ROP]For more details about this operation, see [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 2.2.1.4.1.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopNotify ROP response buffer.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer] RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopNotify] this field is set to 0x2A.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer]NotificationHandle (4 bytes): A Server object handle.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer, NotificationHandle (4 bytes):] This handle specifies the notification server object associated with this notification event.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer] LogonId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer, LogonId (1 byte):] This value specifies the logon associated with this notification event.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer]NotificationData (variable): Various structures.
[In RopNotify ROP Response Buffer, NotificationData (variable):] The various structures for this field are specified in [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 2.2.1.4.1.1.
[In RopPending ROP] The RopPending ROP response notifies the client that there are pending notifications on a session. There is no request buffer for this ROP.
[In RopPending ROP] For more details about this operation[RopPending], see [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 2.2.1.3.4.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopPending ROP response buffer.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer] RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopPending] this field is set to 0x6E.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer] SessionIndex (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RopPending ROP Response Buffer, SessionIndex (2 bytes):] This value specifies which session has pending notifications.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP] The RopBufferTooSmall ROP notifies the client that there is insufficient space to return all ROP responses.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopBufferTooSmall ROP response buffer.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]RopId (1 byte): This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopBufferTooSmall] this field is set to 0xFF.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer] SizeNeeded (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer] SizeNeeded (2 bytes): This value specifies the size required for the ROP output buffer.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]RequestBuffers (variable): An array of bytes.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]RequestBuffers (variable): The size of the array is equal to the size of the space remaining in the ROP output buffer.

[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer]RequestBuffers (variable): This array contains the section of the ROP input buffer that was not executed because of the insufficient size of the ROP output buffer.
[In RopBufferTooSmall ROP Response Buffer] RequestBuffers (variable): The layout of the ROP input buffer and ROP output buffer is specified in section 2.2.1.
[In RopBackoff ROP] The RopBackoff ROP response notifies the client that the server is busy.
[In RopBackoff ROP]And the RopBackoff ROP is requesting that the client retry later.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopBackoff ROP response buffer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopBackoff] this field is set to 0xF9.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] LogonId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, LogonId (1 byte):] This value specifies the logon to which the RopBackoff response applies.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] Duration (4 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, Duration (4 bytes):] This value specifies the number of milliseconds to apply a logon backoff.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] BackoffRopCount (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, BackoffRopCount (1 byte):] This value specifies the number of structures in the BackoffRopData field.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] BackoffRopData (variable): An array of BackoffRop structures.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, BackoffRopData (variable):] The format of the BackoffRop structure is specified in section 2.2.15.2.1.1.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, BackoffRopData (variable):] This array specifies the operations to be backed off and also the backoff duration for each.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] AdditionalDataSize (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, AdditionalDataSize (2 bytes):] This value specifies the size of the AdditionalData field.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer] AdditionalData (variable): An array of bytes.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, AdditionalData (variable):] The size of this field, in bytes, is specified by the AdditionalDataSize field.
[In RopBackoff ROP Response Buffer, AdditionalData (variable):] This array specifies additional information about the backoff response.
[In BackoffRop structure] The following descriptions define valid fields for the BackoffRop structure.
[In BackoffRop structure] RopIdBackoff (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In BackoffRop structure, RopIdBackoff (1 byte):] This index identifies the ROP to apply the ROP backoff to.
[In BackoffRop structure] Duration (4 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In BackoffRop structure, Duration (4 bytes):] This value specifies the number of milliseconds to apply a ROP backoff.
[In RopRelease Rop] The RopRelease ROP releases all resources associated with a Server object.
[In RopRelease Rop] For more details about the dependencies of Server objects, see section 3.1.5.3.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer] The following descriptions define valid fields for the RopRelease ROP request buffer.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer] RopId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] This value specifies the type of ROP.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer, RopId (1 byte):] For this operation[RopRelease] this field is set to 0x01.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer] LogonId (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer, LogonId (1 byte):] This value specifies the logon associated with this operation[RopRelease].
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer]InputHandleIndex (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer, InputHandleIndex (1 byte):] This index specifies the location in the Server object handle table where the handle for the input Server Object is stored.
[In RopRelease ROP Request Buffer, InputHandleIndex (1 byte):] For more information about Server objects, see section 1.3.1.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.
[In Abstract Data Model] This document does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this document.
[In Abstract Data Model] The following abstract data model (ADM) elements are maintained by the client.
[In Abstract Data Model] Logon Collection: A collection of Logon Ids in use.
[In Abstract Data Model] Server Object Handle Collection: A collection of valid Server Object Handles received from the server but not yet released.
[In Higher-Layer Triggered Events] The client creates a ROP input buffer consisting of ROP requests for operations to be performed on the server.
[In Higher-Layer Triggered Events] The client sends the ROP input buffer the server and receives a ROP output buffer back from the server.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] The layout of the ROP input buffer and the ROP output buffer is specified in section 2.2.1.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] A ROP input buffer is constructed by the client and sent to the server.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] The client packages its ROP requests together in the intended processing order and creates an associated Server object handle table.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] When assembling a ROP input buffer, the client MUST use a Server object handle table large enough to include an entry for the largest index used by the ROP requests.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer]Each entry that is referenced only as input for ROPs MUST be filled in with the handle of the Server Object that is intended to be the input of the operation.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] Each entry that is referenced only as output SHOULD be filled in with the 0xFFFFFFFF value.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] Each entry that is referenced first as an output index.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer,Each entry that is referenced first as an output index] and then as input index SHOULD also be initialized to the 0xFFFFFFFF value.

[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] Multiple ROPs in a buffer can use the same Server object handle table index. For example, a RopOpenFolder ROP (section 2.2.4.1) can specify index 1 as the location to place the handle for the folder Server Object.
[In Creating a ROP Input Buffer] In the same ROP input buffer, a RopGetContentsTable ROP (section 2.2.4.14) can specify index 1 as the location for the input Server Object handle.
[In Logging On] The client logs on to a message store by using the RopLogon ROP (section 2.2.3.1) before attempting any additional ROPs on the message store.
[In Logging On] Prior to logging on, the client begins an RPC session by calling the EcDoConnectEx method, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.1.
[In Logging On] Prior to logging on, the client begins an RPC session by calling the Connect request type<13>, as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.1.
[In Logging On] Once the client has successfully connected to the server, the client begins a logon session by sending a RopLogon ROP request (section 2.2.3.1.1).
[In Logging On] Each logon session is identified by a Logon ID created by the client.
[In Logging On] The Logon ID is associated with a Logon object, which is created by the server during its processing of a RopLogon ROP request.
[In Logging On] The Logon ID is initially used in the RopLogon ROP request and is then used in all subsequent ROPs that are issued on the logon session.
[In Logging On] The client specifies the Logon ID in the Logon Id field of the ROP request buffer of each ROP.
[In Logging On] Any 8-bit integer value is allowed for the Logon ID.
[In Logging On, Any 8-bit integer value is allowed for the logon ID] and the client does not have to specify Logon IDs in a certain numeric order.
[In Logging On] The Logon ID MUST be unique per RPC session (that is, per call to the EcDoConnectEx method).
[In Logging On] The client can issue multiple RopLogon ROP requests per RPC session.
[In Logging On] If the client specifies an active Logon ID, then the current logon session is released.
[In Logging On, If the client specifies an active logon ID, the current logon is released] and replaced with the new one.
[In Logging On] The client manages the active Logon ID by use of a Logon Collection abstract data model element.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The client receives the ROP responses in the ROP output buffer.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] These ROP responses appear in the ROP output buffer in the same order as they were sent in the ROP input buffer.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The ROP output buffer can also include ROP responses that do not have corresponding ROP requests in the ROP input buffer.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] These extra ROP responses include the RopBackoff ROP (section 2.2.15.2), the RopBufferTooSmall ROP (section 2.2.15.1), the RopNotify ROP (section 2.2.14.2), and the RopPending ROP (section 2.2.14.3).

[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] Any client reporting its version as 12.00.4228.0000 or later, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.2.4.1.3.2, MUST support processing the RopBackoff ROP response buffer.
[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] The layout of this ROP is specified in section 2.2.14.2.
[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] The RopBackoff ROP can appear at any location within the RopsList field of the ROP output buffer.

[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] This ROP response indicates that the server requests the client delay the resending of ROP requests for the specified logon or for a type of ROP for a specified length time.

[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] When this response contains a nonzero value in the RopIdBackoff field, as specified in section 2.2.15.2.1.1, it specifies the ROP request that is required to be delayed.
[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] The ROP response that was delayed and all subsequent ROP responses will not be in the buffer.
[In Processing the RopBackoff ROP Response] When the BackoffRopCount field, as specified in section 2.2.15.2.1, is set to 0x00, all ROP requests for that logon are to be delayed.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The layout of the RopBufferTooSmall ROP is specified in section 2.2.15.1.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The RopBufferTooSmall ROP response is the last ROP response within the RopsList field of the ROP output buffer, as specified in section 2.2.1.

[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The RopBufferTooSmall ROP response indicates that the size of the ROP output buffer is insufficient to return responses for all of the ROP requests sent.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The RequestBuffers field of the RopBufferTooSmall ROP response includes all ROP requests that were not processed by the server.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The client SHOULD<14> resend the unprocessed ROP requests in a new call to the server via the EcDoRpcExt2 method.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The client SHOULD<14> resend the unprocessed ROP requests in a new call to the server via the Execute request type<15>.

[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] The value that the client specifies in the pcbOut parameter of the EcDoRpcExt2 method MUST be greater than or equal to the value of the SizeNeeded field of the RopBufferTooSmall ROP response.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] For more details about the EcDoRpcExt2 method and the pcbOut parameter, see [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.2.
[In Processing the RopBufferTooSmall Response Buffer] For more details about the Execute request type, see [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.2.

[In RopNotify and RopPending]The RopNotify (section 2.2.14.2) and RopPending (section 2.2.14.3) ROP responses appear at the end of the RopsList field of the ROP output buffer, as specified in section 2.2.1.
[In RopNotify and RopPending] A RopPending ROP response SHOULD<16> be present only if the ROP output buffer does not contain all queued RopNotify ROP responses.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCROPS_R469303, MS-OXCROPS_R4693031.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RopNotify and RopPending] For more details about how the client processes these ROPs, see [MS-OXCNOTIF] section 3.2.5.

[In Subsequent RopProgress ROP Requests]Once the client receives a RopProgress ROP response (section 2.2.8.13), all subsequent RopProgress ROP requests MUST use the same Server object handle table values as those used in the first RopProgress ROP request.
[In Server Object Dependencies] The client MUST use the ROPRelease ROP (section 2.2.15.3) RopRelease to release an object.
[In Server Object Dependencies] The client MUST release an owned object before releasing the object's owner.
[In Server Object Dependencies] For example, a Stream object that is owned by a folder is released before the owning folder is released.
[In Server Object Dependencies] A summary of object owners and the objects that they can own is provided below.
[In Server Object Dependencies, An attachment owns the following:] A Stream object that is opened on properties of the attachment.
[In Server Object Dependencies, An attachment owns the following:] An Embedded Message object that is created from the attachment.

[In Server Object Dependencies ,An attachment owns the following:] A FastTransfer download context that is opened by a RopFastTransferSourceCopyTo ROP (section 2.2.12.6) or a RopFastTransferSourceCopyProperties ROP (section 2.2.12.7).
[In Server Object Dependencies, An attachment owns the following:] A FastTransfer upload context that is opened by a RopFastTransferDestinationConfigure ROP (section 2.2.12.1).
[In Server Object Dependencies, A message owns the following:] An attachment of the message
[In Server Object Dependencies, A message owns the following:] A Stream object that is opened on properties of the message
[In Server Object Dependencies, A message owns the following:] An attachments table that is opened on the message
[In Server Object Dependencies, A message owns the following:] A FastTransfer download context that is opened by a RopFastTransferSourceCopyTo ROP or a RopFastTransferSourceCopyProperties ROP
[In Server Object Dependencies, A message owns the following:] A FastTransfer upload context that is opened by a RopFastTransferDestinationConfigure ROP (section 2.2.12.1)
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:] A Stream object that is opened on properties of the folder
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A rules table that is opened on the folder
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A permissions table that is opened on the folder
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A fast-transfer download context that is opened by a RopFastTransferSourceCopyTo ROP or RopFastTransferSourceCopyProperties ROP

[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A FastTransfer download context that is opened by a RopFastTransferSourceCopyMessages ROP (section 2.2.12.5) or a RopFastTransferSourceCopyFolder ROP (section 2.2.12.4)
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A synchronization download context that is opened by a RopSynchronizationConfigure ROP (section RopSynchronizationConfigure2.2.13.1)
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A FastTransfer upload context that is opened by a RopFastTransferDestinationConfigure ROP
[In Server Object Dependencies, A folder owns the following:]A synchronization upload context that is opened by a RopSynchonizationOpenCollector ROP (section RopSynchronizationOpenCollector2.2.13.7)
[In Code Page for Strings] In a ROP request, the code page for strings MUST match the code page associated with the affected Server object.

[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] If the Server object is owned by a message, then the Server object uses the same code page that the message uses.

[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] The message's properties and the Server objects owned by the message always use the same code page that the message uses.

[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] If the Server object is not owned by a message, then the Server object uses the code page specified in the EcDoConnectEx method or a similar RPC method.

[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] If the Server object is not owned by a message, then the Server object uses the code page specified in the Connect request type<17>.
[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] For more details about the EcDoConnectEx method and RPC, see [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.1.
[In Code Page for Strings,The code page for a Server object is determined as follows:] For more details about the Connect request type, see [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.1.

[In Shutting down] When the client shuts down, before it disconnects from the server, it SHOULD send RopRelease ROP requests (section 2.2.15.3) to the server to clean up all Server Objects it had created but had not yet released.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.
[In Abstract Data Model] This document does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that specified in this document.
[In Abstract Data Model] The following ADM elements are maintained by the server.
[In Abstract Data Model] Logon Map: A mapping of Logon IDs and logon Server objects.
[In Abstract Data Model] Server Object Map: A mapping of Server object handles and Server objects.
[In Abstract Data Model, Server Object Map] There is one map for each logon Server Object.

[In Initialization] When a connection is first set up between a client and server via the ExDoConnectEx method, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.1, the Server Object Map and Logon Map ADM elements are empty.

[In Initialization] When a connection is first set up between a client and server via the Connect request type<18>, as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.1, the Server Object Map and Logon Map ADM elements are empty.
[In Sending Notifications to the Client] When events that the client has registered for occur, the server sends one or more RopNotify ROP responses (section 2.2.14.2).

[In Sending Notifications to the Client] If not all queued RopNotify ROP responses can fit in the ROP output buffer, the server SHOULD<19> include a RopPending ROP response (section 2.2.14.3.1) in the ROP output buffer.
[In Sending Notifications to the Client] More detailed information about notifications can be found in [MS-OXCNOTIF].

[In Sending the RopBackoff ROP Response] When the server determines that a ROP request is required to be delayed, the server MUST either respond with a RopBackoff ROP response (section 2.2.15.2) or fail the ExDoRpcExt2 method, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.2, or the Execute request type,<20> as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.2.

[In Sending the RopBackoff ROP Response] If the server version, as defined in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.1.3.2. is greater than 08.00.0525.0 and the client version, as defined in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.2.4.1.3.2 is greater than 12.0.4228.0, the server SHOULD substitute a RopBackoff ROP response in place of the response for the delayed ROP request.

[In Sending the RopBackoff ROP Response] If either the client or the server are earlier versions, the server MUST instead fail either the ExDoRpcExt2 method by raising the RPC_S_SERVER_TOO_BUSY exception, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC], or the Execute request type with an HTTP status code of 200, a value of 0 (success) in the X-ResponseCode header, and a value of 0x000006BB in the StatusCode field of the Execute request type failure response body, as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP].
[In Sending the RopBackoff ROP Response] If ROPs are specified in a RopBackoff ROP response, all subsequent ROP requests SHOULD NOT be processed.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] When the server determines that there is not enough space in the ROP output buffer, as specified in section 2.2.1, for the remaining ROP responses, it MUST NOT process the remaining ROPs.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] [there is not enough space in the ROP output buffer, as specified in section 2.2.1, for the remaining ROP responses]The server responds in one of the following ways.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] If the ROP output buffer can be resized to accommodate the remaining ROPs, then the server MUST send a RopBufferTooSmall ROP response (section 2.2.15.1).

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] In this case[the ROP output buffer can be resized to accommodate the remaining ROPs], the client can resubmit the ROP requests in a new EcDoRpcExt2 method call with the pcbOut parameter set to an appropriate value, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.2.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] In this case [the ROP output buffer can be resized to accommodate the remaining ROPs], the client can resubmit the ROP requests in a new Execute request type with the MaxRopOut field set to an appropriate value,<21> as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.2.1.
[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] For details about how the client processes a RopBufferTooSmall ROP response, see section 3.1.5.1.2.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] If one of the ROP responses will not fit in the ROP output buffer when either the pcbOut parameter of the EcDoRpcExt2 response, as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.2, is set to the maximum value, then the server SHOULD<22> fail the EcDoRpcExt2 method with a return value of 0x0000047D.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] If one of the ROP responses will not fit in the ROP output buffer when the RopBufferSize field of the Execute request type success response body, as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.2.2, is set to the maximum value, then the server SHOULD fail the Execute request type with a value of 0x0000047D in the StatusCode field.
[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] Some ROP response buffers are dynamically sized based on the amount of available space in the ROP output buffer.

[In Responding to Insufficient Output Buffer Space] If the ROP output buffer is not large enough for the minimum size of a dynamically sized ROP response buffer followed by subsequent ROP response buffers, then the server sends the RopBufferTooSmall ROP.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] The layout of the ROP input buffer is specified in section 2.2.1.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] When processing a ROP input buffer received from a client, the server MUST process the ROP requests in the order they are specified in the ROPList field.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] When processing an input ROP buffer received from a client MUST NOT process more than one ROP input buffer concurrently for a connection.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] The ROP responses in the ROP output buffer MUST be in the same order in which they were processed.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] If the server is unable to parse the ROP requests in the ROP inputbuffer, the RPC MUST fail by returning 0x000004B6.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] During processing of a ROP request, the server resolves the Server object handle table index to a Server Object.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] If the index is invalid, the server SHOULD <23> fails the ROP with the ReturnValue field set to 0x000004B9.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-OXCROPS_R471201, MS-OXCROPS_R4713.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] Any index used for input is converted into the corresponding Server object by looking up the handle in the Server object handle table.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer]Any index used for input then looking up the Server object handle in the Server Object Map ADM element associated with the logon for the ROP request.
[In Processing a Input ROP Buffer] If any lookup in the Logon Map ADM element fails, the server SHOULD<24> fill in a failure ROP response with a nonzero return value.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] After successful processing of a ROP request that created a Server object, the server MUST assign an unused Server object handle to the object.

[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer, After successful execution of a ROP request that created a Server object, the server MUST assign an unused Server object handle to the object] And record the mapping in the Server Object Map ADM element for the logon associated with the Rop.
[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] The handle assigned is then set in the Server object handle table at the location specified by the output index in the ROP request.

[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer,The handle assigned is then set in the Server object handle table at the location specified by the output index in the ROP request] And can be used by subsequent ROP requests in the same ROP input buffer.

[In Processing a ROP Input Buffer] Because the Server object handle value 0xFFFFFFFF is used to initialize unused entries of a Server object handle table, a server MUST NOT assign that value to a created Server Object.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The format of the ROP output buffer is specified in section 2.2.1.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The server constructs the ROP output buffer after processing the ROP input buffer.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The ROP output buffer includes a list of ROP responses.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The ROP output buffer includes a modified Server object handle table.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The ROP responses in the ROP output buffer MUST be in the same order in which they were processed.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The Server object handle table MUST be large enough to contain an entry for the highest Server object handle table index specified in the ROP responses.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The table can be a smaller size compared to the table in the ROP input buffer if entries at the end of the table were not referenced.
[In Creating a ROP Output Buffer] The server MUST preserve the order of entries in the Server object handle table between the ROP input buffer and the ROP output buffer.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] When the server receives a RopRelase ROP request, as specified in section 2.2.15.3.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] The server MUST remove the mapping for the Server object handle from the Server Object Map ADM element.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] The server MUST release the resources associated with it.<25>
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] The same Server object handle can now be reused for another Server Object.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] If the Server Object specified is a logon Server Object, then the server MUST also remove it from the Logon Map ADM element.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] Unlike all other ROP requests, the RopRelease ROP does not have any associated ROP response.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] The server MUST not return any response for a RopRelease ROP request.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-OXCROPS_R4581.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] The server MUST not return response for a RopRelease ROP request.
[In Processing the RopRelease ROP Request] Any errors resulting from the processing of this ROP MUST be ignored and not sent back to the client.

[in Error Codes Returned When an Object Is Invalid]ecInvalidObject [value] 0x80040108 [Meaning]Returned when the client attempts to reuse any Server object handle that the server has previously issued a RopRelease ROP on and that hasn't been recycled for a new object.

[in Error Codes Returned When an Object Is Invalid]ecNullObject [value] 0x000004B9 [Meaning] Returned when the client attempts to use a Server object handle value that was never assigned to an open object.
[in Error Codes Returned When an Object Is Invalid]ecAccessDenied [value] 0x80070005 [Meaning] Returned when the client attempts to use the Server object handle from a different logon.
[In Disconnecting] When the client disconnects, the server MUST release all Server Objects, Logon Map ADM elements, and Server Object Map ADM elements associated with the connection.

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, any statement of optional behavior in this specification that is prescribed using the terms SHOULD or SHOULD NOT implies product behavior in accordance with the SHOULD or SHOULD NOT prescription.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, the term MAY implies that the product does not follow the prescription.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<1> Section 2.1: Exchange 2003 follows this behavior.)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<1> Section 2.1: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010 and the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <1> Section 2.1: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Execute request type.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <1> Section 2.1: The Execute request type was introduced in Outlook 2013 SP1.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Execute request type. (<1> Section 2.1: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<2> Section 2.2.1: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010 and the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <2> Section 2.2.1: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Execute request type.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <2> Section 2.2.1: The Execute request type was introduced in Outlook 2013 SP1.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Execute request type. (<2> Section 2.2.1: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation behavior is undefined when they encounter a reserved value in a RopId field.(<3> Section 2.2.2: Exchange 2007 behavior is undefined when they encounter a reserved value in a RopId field.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does return an error for the RPC ,as specified in [MS-OXCRPC] section 3.1.4.12, when it encounters a RopId value that is associated with a reserved ROP. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<4> Section 2.2.2: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010 and the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <4> Section 2.2.2: Office Outlook 2003, Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Execute request type.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <4> Section 2.2.2: The Execute request type was introduced in Outlook 2013 SP1.

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does return an error for the Execute request type when the server encounters a RopId value that is associated with a reserved ROP. (<4> Section 2.2.2: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not set the PerUserGuid field to an empty GUID. (<5> Section 2.2.3.1.3: Exchange 2007 does not set the PerUserGuid field to an empty GUID.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] PerUserGuid (16 bytes): Implementation does set this field to an empty GUID (all zeroes). (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not use the RopOptionsData ROP . <6> Section 2.2.7.9: Outlook 2010 does not use the RopOptionsData ROP (section 2.2.7.9).

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not return [OptionsInfo (variable) field as] an empty array in the OptionsInfo field. (<7> Section 2.2.7.9.2: Exchange 2007, and Exchange 2010 do not return an empty array in the OptionsInfo field.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does return this field[OptionsInfo] as an empty array. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2013 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does set the ReturnValue field for the RopOptionsData ROP response (section 2.2.7.9) to 0x00000000 regardless of the failure of the ROP. (<8> Section 2.2.7.9.3: Exchange 2007 sets the ReturnValue field for the RopOptionsData ROP response (section 2.2.7.9) to 0x00000000 regardless of the failure of the ROP.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] ReturnValue (4 bytes): For this response[Failure Response], Implementation does set this field to a value other than 0x00000000. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <9> Section 2.2.9.2.1: Exchange 2003 limits the stream size to 32 kilobytes.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <9> Section 2.2.9.2.1: [Exchange 2003 limits the stream size to 32 kilobytes.] Therefore, if the value of the ByteCount field in the RopReadStream ROP request buffer (section 2.2.9.2) is greater than 0x8000, the server returns the RopBufferTooSmall ROP (section 2.2.15.1).

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <9> Section 2.2.9.2.1: [Exchange 2003 limits the stream size to 32K bytes.] The MaximumByteCount field is never present in the request buffer because the ByteCount field is never set to 0xBABE.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <10> Section 2.2.9.6.1: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 do not use a configuration setting.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <10> Section 2.2.9.6.1: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 always limit the maximum size of the stream to 231 bytes.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not set the field[ReadByteCount] to 0x0000000000000000, but the non zero value has no meaning. (<11> Section 2.2.9.8.3: Exchange 2007 do not set the field to 0x0000000000000000, but the nonzero value has no meaning.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] For this response [of read from the source object ] , Implementation does set this field[ReadByteCount] to 0x0000000000000000. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not set the field[WrittenByteCount] to 0x0000000000000000, but the non zero value has no meaning. (<12> Section 2.2.9.8.3: Exchange 2007 do not set the field to 0x0000000000000000, but the nonzero value has no meaning.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] For this response [of written to the destination object], Implementation does set this field[WrittenByteCount] to 0x0000000000000000. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation doesn't support the Connect request type. (<13> Section 3.1.4.2: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010, the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <13> Section 3.1.4.2: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Connect request type.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Connect request type. (<13> Section 3.1.4.2: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <13> Section 3.1.4.2: Office Outlook 2013 SP1 does support the Connect request type.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the first ROP in the RPC buffer creates a response that exceeds the maximum ROP buffer size and there are no additional ROPs in the RPC buffer, then the implementation does return the ecBufferTooSmall error to fail the ROP instead of returning the RopBufferTooSmall ROP (section 2.2.15.1). (Update Rollup 3 for Exchange 2010 SP2 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <14> Section 3.1.5.1.2: Failing the ROP when it satisfies these conditions[In Update Rollup 3 for Exchange 2010 SP2, if the first ROP in the RPC buffer creates a response that exceeds the maximum ROP buffer size and there are no additional ROPs in the RPC buffer] indicates to the client that there is no client action possible to make that ROP response fit in the ROP buffer.

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<15> Section 3.1.5.1.2: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010 and the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <15> Section 3.1.5.1.2: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Execute request type.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <15> Section 3.1.5.1.2: The Execute request type was introduced in Outlook 2013 SP1.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Execute request type. (<15> Section 3.1.5.1.2: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does include a RopPending ROP response (section 2.2.14.3) even though the ROP output buffer contains all queued RopNotify ROP responses (section 2.2.14.2). (<16> Section 3.1.5.1.3: Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not include a RopPending ROP response if the ROP output buffer contain all queued RopNotify ROP responses. (Exchange 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation doesn't support the Connect request type. (<17> Section 3.1.5.4: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010, the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <17> Section 3.1.5.4: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Connect request type.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Connect request type. (<17> Section 3.1.5.4: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <17> Section 3.1.5.4: Office Outlook 2013 SP1 does support the Connect request type.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation doesn't support the Connect request type. (<18> Section 3.2.3: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010, the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <18> Section 3.2.3: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Connect request type.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Connect request type. (<18> Section 3.2.3: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <18> Section 3.2.3: Office Outlook 2013 SP1 does support the Connect request type.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <19> Section 3.2.4.1: Exchange 2007 sometimes include a RopPending ROP response (section 2.2.14.3) even though all queued RopNotify ROP responses (section 2.2.14.2) fit in the ROP output buffer.

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support the Execute request type. (<20> Section 3.2.4.3: Exchange 2007, Exchange 2010 and the initial release of Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <20> Section 3.2.4.3: Office Outlook 2007, Outlook 2010, and the initial release of Outlook 2013 do not support the Execute request type.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] <20> Section 3.2.4.3: The Execute request type was introduced in Outlook 2013 SP1.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the Execute request type. (<20> Section 3.2.4.3: Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does not fail the EcDoRpcExt2 remote procedure call RPC and instead fail the individual ROP with the ReturnValue field of the ROP response buffer set to 0x0000047D if one of the ROP responses will not fit in the ROP output buffer when either the pcbOut parameter of EcDoRpcExt2 response is set to the maximum value. (<22> Section 3.2.4.3: Exchange 2007 do not fail the EcDoRpcExt2 RPC and instead fail the individual ROP with the ReturnValue field of the ROP response buffer set to 0x0000047D.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If one of the ROP responses will not fit in the ROP output buffer when either the pcbOut parameter of EcDoRpcExt2 response is set to the maximum value, then implementation does fail the EcDoRpcExt2 method with a return value of 0x0000047D. (Exchange 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If one of the ROP responses will not fit in the ROP output buffer when the RopBufferSize field of the Execute request type success response body, as specified in [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP] section 2.2.4.2.2, is set to the maximum value, then implementation does fail the Execute request type with a value of 0x0000047D in the StatusCode field. (Exchange 2013 SP1 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] For some ROPs, Implementation does use different methods to resolve the Server object and, therefore, do not fail the ROP if the index is invalid. (<23> Section 3.2.5.1: For some ROPs, Exchange 2007 use different methods to resolve the Server object and, therefore, do not fail the ROP if the index is invalid.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the index is invalid, implementation does fail the ROP with the ReturnValue field set to 0x000004B9. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2010 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does fail the RPC if any lookup in the Logon Map ADM element fails. ( <24> Section 3.2.5.1: Exchange 2007 fail the RPC.)

[In Processing a Input ROP Buffer] Implementation does fill in a failure ROP response with a nonzero return value if any lookup in the Logon Map ADM element fails. (Exchange 2010 and above follows this behavior.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <25> Section 3.2.5.3: In instances where multiple ROPs are being processed in one RPC and the RopRelease ROP is the last ROP in the call, implementation does replace the handle of the released Server object handle table entry with a value that is considered invalid by both server and client and is not 0xFFFFFFFF. This invalid handle value is then returned as the Server object handle in the ROP responses for the other ROPs in the RPC. (Exchange 2010 follows this behavior.)
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does release the resources associated with it. (Exchange 2007, Exchange 2013 and above follow this behavior.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If MaximumByteCount is greater than 0x80000000, then Implementation does fail with error code 0x000004B6. (Microsoft Exchange Server 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopGetStoreState remote operation (ROP). (Exchange 2007 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support asynchronous operations(RopAbort) on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags, as described in section 2.2.2.1.4. (Exchange 2007 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support asynchronous operations(RopGetStatus) on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags, as described in section 2.2.2.1.4. (Exchange 2007 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] For RopExpandRow, implementation does support a value greater than 0 for the MaxRowCount field. (Exchange 2007 and Exchange 2010 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the RopgetValidAttachments ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopCopyToStream ROP. (Exchange 2007 and Exchange 2013 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopProgress ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.8.13). (Exchange 2007 and Exchange 2013 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopLockRegionStream ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopUnlockRegionStream ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopCloneStream ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] If a folder with the name given by the DisplayName field of the request buffer (RopCreateFolder) already exists, implementation does set a nonzero value to IsExistingFolder field. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support this specification [MS-OXCMAPIHTTP]. (Exchange Server 2013 Service Pack 1 (SP1) follows this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Implementation does support this given protocol sequence [ncacn_ip_tcp]. ( Microsoft Exchange Server 2007 and 2010 follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PropertyProblem Structure] Index (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In PropertyProblem Structure] PropertyTag (4 bytes): A PropertyTag structure, as specified in section 2.9.
[In PropertyProblem Structure] ErrorCode (4 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In FlaggedPropertyRow Structure] Flag (1 byte): An unsigned integer.
[In FlaggedPropertyRow Structure] ValueArray (variable): An array of variable-sized structures.
[In RecipientRow Structure]AddressPrefixUsed (optional) (1 byte): Unsigned integer.
[In RecipientRow Structure] DisplayType (optional) (1 byte): An enumeration.
[In RecipientRow Structure] Valid values [0x00, 0x01, 0x02, 0x03, 0x04, 0x05, 0x06] for this field [DisplayType (optional) (1 byte)] are specified in the following table.
[In RecipientRow Structure] EntryIdSize (optional) (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RecipientRow Structure] SearchKeySize (optional) (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RecipientRow Structure] RecipientColumnCount (2 bytes): An unsigned integer.
[In RecipientRow] RecipientColumnCount (2 bytes): This value [RecipientColumnCount] specifies the number of columns from the RecipientColumns field that are included in the RecipientProperties field.
[In PropertyTag Structure] PropertyType (2 bytes): An unsigned integer that identifies the data type of the property value, as specified by the table in section 2.11.1.
[In PropertyTag Structure] PropertyId (2 bytes): An unsigned integer that identifies the property.
[In TaggedPropertyValue Structure] PropertyTag (4 bytes): A PropertyTag structure, as specified in section 2.9, giving the values of the PropertyId and PropertyType fields for the property.
[In RopGetStoreState ROP] The RopGetStoreState ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.3.5) is used to obtain state information about the current mailbox.<10>

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] The implementation does implement the RopGetStoreState remote operation (ROP). (<10> Section 2.2.1.5: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 does implement the RopGetStoreState remote operation (ROP) ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.3.5))
[In RopAbort ROP] The RopAbort ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.5.5) attempts to stop any asynchronous table operations that are currently in progress.<10>
[In RopGetStatus ROP] The RopGetStatus ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.5.6) retrieves information about the current status of asynchronous operations being performed on the table.<12>

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support asynchronous operations on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags. (<10> Section 2.2.2.6: Exchange 2010, Exchange 2013, and Exchange 2016 do not support asynchronous operations on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags, as described in section 2.2.2.1.4.)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support asynchronous operations on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags. (<12> Section 2.2.2.7: Exchange 2010, Exchange 2013, and Exchange 2016 do not support asynchronous operations on tables and ignore the TABL_ASYNC flags, as described in section 2.2.2.1.4.)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not support a value greater than 0 for the MaxRowCount field. (<16> Section 2.2.2.17.1: Exchange 2013 and Exchange 2016 do not support a value greater than 0 for the MaxRowCount field.)

[In RopGetValidAttachments ROP] The RopGetValidAttachments ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.6.18) gets the attachment IDs for all attachments that have previously been saved and have been assigned a valid numeric identifier.<18>
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does support the RopGetValidAttachments ROP. (Exchange 2007 follows this behavior.)
[In Processing RopCopyToStream] Servers SHOULD<13> implement this ROP [RopCopyToStream].
[In Processing RopProgress] Servers SHOULD<14> implement this ROP [RopProgress].
[In Processing RopLockRegionStream] Servers MAY<15> implement this ROP [RopLockRegionStream].
[In Processing RopUnlockRegionStream] Servers MAY<16> implement this ROP [RopUnlockRegionStream].
[In Processing RopWriteAndCommitStream] Servers MAY<17> implement this ROP [RopWriteAndCommitStream].
[In Processing RopCloneStream] Servers MAY<18> implement this ROP [RopCloneStream].

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, any statement of optional behavior in this specification that is prescribed using the terms SHOULD or SHOULD NOT implies product behavior in accordance with the SHOULD or SHOULD NOT prescription.
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, the term MAY implies that the product does not follow the prescription.

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not implement the RopCopyToStream ROP. (<13> Section 3.2.5.18: The initial release version of Exchange 2010 does not implement the RopCopyToStream ROP.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does not implement the RopProgress ROP. (<14> Section 3.2.5.19: The initial release version of Exchange 2010 does not implement the RopProgress ROP.)
[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopLockRegionStream ROP. (<15> Section 3.2.5.20: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 implement the RopLockRegionStream ROP.)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopUnlockRegionStream ROP. (<16> Section 3.2.5.21: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 implement the RopUnlockRegionStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.10).)

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP. (<17> Section 3.2.5.22: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 implement the RopWriteAndCommitStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.11.))

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does implement the RopCloneStream ROP. (<18> Section 3.2.5.23: Exchange 2003 and Exchange 2007 implement the RopCloneStream ROP ([MS-OXCROPS] section 2.2.9.12).)

[RopCreateFolder ROP Response Buffer] IsExistingFolder (1 byte): A Boolean value that is nonzero (TRUE) if a public folder with the name given by the DisplayName field of the request buffer (section 2.2.1.2.1) already exists.<3>

[In Appendix A: Product Behavior] Implementation does return zero (FALSE) in the IsExistingFolder field regardless of the existence of the named public folder. <3> Section 2.2.1.2.2: Exchange 2010 Exchange 2013 and Exchange 2016 always return zero (FALSE) in the IsExistingFolder field regardless of the existence of the named public folder.
